title: Score After Flipping Matrix
description: You are given a binary matrix of size m x n. You can flip the elements of any row or any column, which means changing all 0s to 1s and all 1s to 0s in that row or column. After making any number of flips, you want to determine the maximum possible score of the matrix. The score of the matrix is defined as the sum of the integers in each row when viewed as binary numbers. Find the maximum score you can achieve.
input_format: A 2D list of integers representing the binary matrix.
output_format: An integer representing the maximum score that can be achieved.

examples.explanation: After flipping the first and second row, the matrix becomes [[1,1,0],[0,1,0],[1,1,0]]. The binary numbers are 6, 2, and 6. Their sum is 6 + 2 + 6 = 14.
Flipping the second row leads to maximum possible score, yielding the matrix [[1, 1, 0], [1, 1, 1], [1, 0, 1]], with the binary numbers 6, 7, and 5 whose sum is 18.

hints: Analyze the contribution of each column to the binary score.
Flipping a column affects all rows; consider the count of 1's in each column.
Ensure you maximize the contribution of the binary rows.

title: Find the Index of the First Occurrence in a String
description: Given two strings, 'haystack' and 'needle', return the index of the first occurrence of 'needle' in 'haystack', or -1 if 'needle' is not part of 'haystack'. You must implement this function using O(n) time complexity.
input_format: Two strings, 'haystack' and 'needle', where 0 <= haystack.length <= 5 * 10^4 and 0 <= needle.length <= 5 * 10^4.
output_format: An integer representing the index of the first occurrence of 'needle' in 'haystack', or -1 if not found.
hints: Consider using the built-in string methods.
You can iterate through 'haystack' and check the substring starting from each index.
